title: opinion-need-wind-change-says-mp
story: WESTMINSTER voting arrangements may be farcical, but parliament still affords an opportunity to question ministers.I asked the business secretary about grid transmission charges. As offshore wind increases in scale and importance, itrsquos here that much of its energy lands. Cockenzie and Torness are transmission points, eventurbines are sited out at sea.Therersquos room for many more, and the scale of the turbines is far bigger than those onshore, causing less aggravation yet producing more power. Scotlandrsquos ideally placed to benefit, with our weather ndash which we often curse ndash being to our advantage. Itrsquos reckoned that  per cent of Europersquos wind resource blows off our shores.That should be a blessing, being clean and plentul. But ensuring that we benefit is what matters. At the moment grid charges, dictating the cost of transmitting energy, mitigate against sites in Scotland and the north of England. Itrsquos perverse as thatrsquos where theyrsquore located yet itrsquos made most expensive to locate or produce from here.As I said to the Tory minister, Scotland missed out on its oil and gas wealth. As we now, rightly, have a renewables revolution, it cannot miss out again. Not just these renewable energy resources but the onshore manufacturing jobs are badly needed.More widely, many constituents were in touch about the UK Governmentrsquos plans to merge the Department for International Development into the Foreign Office. I share their concerns and am raising them.Organisations such as SCIAF, who I know well, rightly point out that it should be about addressing the needs of people and assisting developing countries, not promoting British foreign policy. This is a moral argument, not an administrative arrangement. Whatever challenges we face, the plight of others is far worse.Finally, I wish Iain Gray well. Our paths have crossed in Holyrood and now here. Wersquove disagreed on Scotlandrsquos constitutional situation but have agreed on much more. Hersquos a man of principle and has served the constituency well.

title: schoolboy-ends-lockdown-boredom-marathon-fundraiser
story: William, , from Gford, decided to set himself a fundraising challenge to help others and keep fit, and pledged to run .miles before the end of June.In just the first three days, he nearly reached the halfway mark by clocking up . miles.The youngster takes to local paths to run and has been accompanied by mum Emily or a friend on a bicycle during his outings.Emily said: ldquoWilliam wanted to do something which would help others and we decided to raise funds for Cancer Research UK because it is something which affects everyone.ldquoThe challenge is a welcome distraction for him as lockdown continues, and he is enjoying it.William, who lives with parents Emily and Thomas Arkwright and younger sister Matilda, uses a tracking app while he runs, which records his routes and distances covered.The youngster, who attends St Maryrsquos School, Melrose, clocked up more than seven miles on one trip, after he was joined by friend Henry on his bicycle to give him moral support.And he is determined to meet his target, with more than pound already donated to his cause.To support Williamrsquos marathon run, go to givepenny donate williamarkwright_marathon_month_challenge

title: mediator-services-solve-lockdown-conflict
story: Robin Burley, an Inveresk resident, and Malcolm Currie, from Musselburgh, are supporting a new mediation service launched across Scotland with help from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Wellbeing Fund.Conflicts can include a personal relationship that is under duress as a result of self-isolation or a dispute with an employer about ing to work during the Covid- outbreak.Anyone is eligible for the service : they live in Scotland the conflict is connected to social distancing or self-isolation it is not part of a pre-existing dispute, for example, orce proceedings or formal contact arrangements and all of the people in the conflict agree to participate in mediation.Provided by a group of professional volunteer mediators, the service is free to iniduals and organisations with up to five employees.Organisations with more than five employees will be charged pound for up to one dayrsquos mediation. The service can be accessed through the Scottish Mediation website or by emailing admin@scottishmediation.org.uk.Mr Currie founded Strathesk Resolutions after more than a decade working as a trades union negotiator.Engaging with employers in the private, public and third sectors, he developed his expertise in collective bargaining, dispute resolution and tackling complex inidual cases.These skills were built on a foundation of over  years advising and influencing countryside managers in relation to land management and pulling together funding packages from wide-ranging sources for joint projects.He has helped organisations as erse as aircraft engineering, academic research institutes, heritage bodies and charitable trusts to establish effective workforce consultation mechanisms, and to operate them to the greatest effect for company performance.Mr Currie said: ldquoAs with any disagreement or dispute,we arenrsquot able to have a conversation about it andit remains unresolved, the frustration that can create can end up being greater than the original reason why there was a disagreement.ldquoThat can often have impacts on mental health and wellbeing so it is goodpeople are able to speak about whatrsquos happening.Mr Burley has been mediating for  years, having carried out more than  mediations which draw on his mediation training and  years of work and le experience in housing, community care and organisational governance.His mediation practice has developed with its focus on civil justice mediation, employment, workplace, commercial, construction, property, urban, rural, agricultural and complaints.He initially trained with Core Solutions in  and, after taking a degree course in mediation and conflict resolution at Strathclyde University, he gained a masterrsquos degree with distinction in .He stood down from six years as chairman of Scottish Mediation in .Prior to working as a mediator and coach, he spent  years in housing and care services and urban development.He was chief executive of the Edin Group, a past chair of Blackwood, ELCAP and the Built Environment Forum Scotland .He has also held non-executive director positions with NHS Lothian, Queen Margaret University and the Scottish Federation of Housing Associations.Mr Burley commented: ldquoMediators are able to help create the space for that conversation in a way which allows the parties to use creative ways of resolving disagreements and in some instances to repair relationships, too.ldquoIn terms of what might be a suitable dispute for mediation, we will be able to speak to you about your dispute and advise on each instance.ldquoAs a general guide, the sorts of disputes include those around family matters, including care of older relatives, flatmates housemates, landlord tenant, co-operative or social housing, workplace concerns related to working from home or shared workspaces and those involving neighbours.ldquoIt is possible that some issues may have existed before and were being managed successfully but the additional pressures have pushed them into conflict.Graham Boyack, director of Scottish Mediation, added: ldquoThis is a challenging time for everyone and the isolation and stress of living in close quarters can cause, or increase, conflict for families, friends, and roommates, and can create challenges for work teams, charities and businesses.

title: crossing-point-creatures-habit
story: IN MANY ways, we are all creatures of habit. Our well-practised routines give a sense of order and wellbeing with the familiar providing a comforting security blanket that we appreciate.Our interests and associations stimulate us and our work and our relationships define and enliven us. We are social beings after all. Take away any of these things from our lives and we feel diminished and threatened and somewhat insecure and deflated.That is why we have found this pandemic such a trial and threat. It has robbed us of so much that we hold dear . It has unsettled and rattled us as it has chocked off so much of the patterns and rhythms of our daily living that we cherish.We donrsquot like to be ruled or controlled by anything that poses a threat or curtails our freedom making us feel vulnerable and helpless. The tedium of inactivity or boredom for some, while for others, the demands or dficulties of family le or work has made for a testing and trying time.Many have turned to prayer and to Godrsquos word at this time, trusting that God knows our plight and hears our cry and has things to say to us in his word, the bible.We can trust in our politicians, scientic advisors and our NHS staffbut even they have their human limitations.To believe in a higher and sovereign hand upon us makes all the dference.The writer of the psalmsin the bible says: lsquoI trust in you, O Lord. My times are in your handsrsquo.Is God seeking to draw us to himself that we might know his mercy and his love in our time of need  Faith in God puts fear to flight and brings peace to our troubled hearts. Jesus said: lsquoDo not let your hearts be troubled. Trust in God trust also in me rsquo.He died on the cross that we might live and by his saving grace, have a hope that triumphs in le and in death.

title: opinion-educating-schoolchildren-priority
story: OUR kids need to be back in school, as soon and as often as possible. We know that the children being worst hit by this time out of school are those from the least privileged backgrounds.The council is working to try to get children back to school but the current government proposals are not acceptable.They aim for the majority of primary schools to have  per cent of pupils attending at any one time and some primary schools to have only  per cent of pupils attending at a time.In our high schools it is a similar story of, at best, having only  per cent of pupils attending at any one time.Part of the issue is that Scottish Government guidance on two-metre social distancing massively limits the number of children who can be in class at any one time.Of course, as we have seen this week, confusion exists in the government as to how education will be delivered in the long term any- way.John Swinney explained that the proposed blended learning arrangements are likely to last for most of the next academic year, only for Nicola Sturgeon to suggest these proposals are merely a contingency plan.This uncertainty creates many dficulties as we plan.For example, how do we get children to school from home The council currently provides transport to get children to schools but, as stands, it will not be sufficient and will need to be radically increased in scope.Council officers suggest that this could mean the cost ballooning to ldquoin excess of pound. million and therefore well beyond existing resource levels, in part due to the two-metre social distancing requirement.But, even with a smaller distance, there will still be signicant dficulty in our schools.We should look at utilising other public buildings such as community centres and sports halls for education purposes.However, this then comes to the crux of the matter: there are signicant resourcing issues with reopening schools.The Scottish Government has asked councils and schools to operate and act in new and radical ways but has not come forward in a meaningful way to assist them.The Scottish Government must help us fund the cost of transporting children to school and help to fund the opening up of other public buildings.Providing an education to our children here in East Lothian needs to be among our very highest priorities.That is why my Conservatives colleagues on the councilrsquos education committee, which is meeting this week, will be pushing officers to try to get children back in school sooner and quicker.

title: pictures-east-linton-enjoys-stay-home-gala
story: The gala committee were forced to cancel the annual day, due to take place on Saturday, June , but decided instead to hold a socially distant event instead.With the theme of Masquerade, locals decorated their homes and planned to have picnics in their gardens and wear masks.Sadly the rain meant most picnics were unable to go ahead but the local fire crew arrived and drove through the village streets handing out treats provided by the committee.Children were encouraged to draw pictures of a fire engine and put them on display at their homes to attract the firefighters attention and families turned out to wave to the crew with some some lucky youngsters even given the chance to climb into the fire engine cab.Station Commander David Ward, of the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service, said: ldquoWe were delighted that members of our crew at East Linton Fire Station could take part in their community gala."With so many gala days and local events cancelled, itrsquos great to see people come together in this way to try and create something positive for the local community, and children especially. The day was a success, and our firefighters were delighted to be able to show their support and gratitude to the local community during this testing period.

title: pledge-made-august-12-school-return-planned
story: On Tuesday, Depute First Minister John Swinney told the Scottish Parliament that he believed classes could resume nationally with no social distancing measures requiredprogress against Covid- continued over the summer.And East Lothianrsquos education chief has pledged to work with headteachers to ensure parents are kept informed throughout the summer holidays as the council continues to follow national guidance and work towards welcoming students back.Lesley Brown, chief operating officer education, acknowledged that it had been an anxious time for parents and teaching staff.But she said: ldquoKeeping families and staff informed over the last few months has been a priority for us."This weekrsquosannouncement makes it even more important that we involve parents every step of the way so they have confidence in our plans for ato school after the summer holidays.Schools across East Lothian had been preparing to welcome pupils back after the school holidays using a blended model which would have seen pupils at school part-time and no school at all on Fridays.Two-metre distancing would also have been in place.Classrooms at some schools had already been redesigned to follow the two-metre rule and hand sanitising stations set up at entrances and classrooms.Mrs Brown said that while the new government plan was welcomed, the work which had gone into preparing for the former proposals would stand the county in good stead should there be a spike in the virus or a change to plans.She said: ldquoWe have contingency plans in place for social distancing should they be needed and are in a better position because of the extensive planning we have done already.ldquoIn the event all children come back in August we do not know what September and October will look like and there is concern about a winter spike.ldquoOur contingency planning means we will be ready.Mrs Brown said headteachers would work through the summer holidays with education bosses to keep parents up to date as more details of the new plans were confirmed.She said: ldquoOur headteachers have already put in place procedures to keep parents informed and we will be in touch through the summer holidays.ldquoThis is a unique situation we are all in and we aim to make sure everyone is kept informed.ldquoI feel for parents and understand their anxiety as well as those of our teaching staff as we move into this new phase but we aim to be as open and upfront as possible as we go forward.ldquoWe had a huge uptake of home learning with  per cent of pupils logging in and were very successful when compared to other local authorities.ldquoI think we should look for the positive things we can take from the experience. Some pupils may have learnt new skills and may be rethinking their path because of new experiences and we look forward to hearing about those experiences.ldquoMore importantly, we look forward to welcoming our children back to school and are excited to see them again in August.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet spokesperson for education and childrenrsquos wellbeing, praised the efforts of parents, carers and teaching staff during lockdown.She said: ldquoStaff across our schools especially our headteachers have been working tirelessly and around the clock to pull together plans based on government advice.ldquoMany parents and carers will be pleased to hear that schools will be going back full-time in August. We are making sure that our plans put the safety of our pupils and staff first and for this we have to be fully funded.

title: eight-famous-film-locations-scotland-can-visit-lockdown-eases
story: But its not just our famous faces that make it to the screen - its our scenery too.Our country has played host to a surprising number of films - from Hollywood blockbusters like Avengers and James Bond, to Scottish favourites like Trainspotting and Outlaw King.With the five-mile limit on travel for leisure set to end in Scotland on July , and hotels set to reopen on July  - weve pulled together alist of the best on-screen locations across the country to visit once lockdown eases.Harry PotterWhere: Glenfinnan, Highlands,The famous Glenfinnan Viaduct features in both the second and third Harry Potter films ndash with the Hogwarts Express even calling at Glenfinnan station.Tourists flock to the area every year for the stunning scenery surrounding the railway ndash perched ft above the ground.SkyfallWhere: Glen Etive, HighlandsJames Bondrsquos epic Skyfall experience saw him in Istanbul, a skyscraper in Shanghai and an abandoned island in Japan.But it was the breath-taking scenes in Glencoe that captured the eye of  fans across the globe.TrainspottingWhere: EdinburghAn iconic film based right in Scotlandrsquos capital, itrsquos almost dficult to NOT find yourself near one of the sets for the Trainspotting films.Almost half the scenes of T were filmed right in the city ndash from Renton and Spudrsquos run around Holyrood Park and Arthurrsquos Seat, to the epic escape from the nightclub through Edinburghrsquos Old Town.And who can forget the original opening scene ndash with drug-afflicted Renton sprinting down Princes Street to the sound of Iggy Pop.Outlaw KingWhere: VariousDiving deep into the legends of one of Scotlandrsquos most important historical figures, it makes sense for a film about a travelling outlaw to be set across ious dferent locations in Scotland.From the Catheral in Glasgow, to Scone Palace just outside Perth ndash there is plenty of Robert the Bruce history to keep you occupied on a tour of the country.Full details of Outlaw King locations can be found here.Avengers: Infinity WarWhere: EdinburghOnce again the capital played host to a major blockbuster film ndash Marvelrsquos Avengers: Infinity War ndash back in .And as the only location outside of a studio to be used in the film, Edinburgh is truly a star of the film.Cockburn Street in the cityrsquos Old Town first appears when Scarlet Witch and Vision stand outside a fast-food restaurant.The Royal Mile then became a thrilling backstop in the film, with convincing explosions and breath-taking action scenes.Avengers: EndgameWhere: St Abbs, BordersOne of the most successful films of all time, Avengers: Endgame also used Scotland as the location for some of its scenes.The fishing village of St Abbs in the Borders was renamed lsquoNew Asgardrsquo, and saw movie star Chris Hemsworthdescend on the town to film some scenes.According to the local leboat, who have jokingly said the village is now lsquotwinnedrsquo with the fictional village, the filmmakers Marvel made a ldquogenerous donation to the leboat.World War ZWhere: George Square, GlasgowIn ,  cast and crew ndash including Brad Pitt ndash descended on the streets of Glasgow city centre to film the zombie blockbuster World War Z.American cars and street lights were brought in to resemble Philadelphia, the filmrsquos setting.George Square can be seen from  seconds in this trailer here:Where: Govan Graving Docks, GlasgowOscar and Bafta-award-winning war epic  is one of the newer films to be shot in Scotland - but its success is just as prominent as the rest.Co-writtenby GlaswegianKrysty Wilson-Cairns, some of the films most suspenseful scenes come right on our doorstep - with the Govan Graving Docks on the River Clyde used to replicate a war-torn area as the main character battles in arace against time behind enemy territory to try save fellow soldiers from a trap.

title: preston-athletic-footballers-getting-bikes-good-causes
story: Members of Prestonpans-based Preston Athleticrsquos squad are getting on their bikes for a special fundraiser, which will see them visit the homes of  football teams in East Lothian, Edinburgh and Midlothian.Money raised will be split between the East of Scotland side and the NHS, as a thank you for the hard work of its staff.The cycle, had been due to take place last Saturday but was postponed to a still-to-be-confirmed new date, was the idea of team-mates Kai Austin and Nathan Stokes.Twenty-one-year-old Kai, who plays right back for the side, said: ldquoA lot of clubs have been making signings and we knew Preston were struggling even to just keep going.ldquoI have seen where someone has cycled or driven to the  league grounds [in the Scottish Premiership to League Two].ldquoWe thought maybe it would be a cool idea to do something like that at our level.ldquoWe came up with a challenge to entice people to want to donate and will us on.ldquoWe came up with visiting  grounds for  teams for the   season.The teammates plan to start at New Countess Park, home of Dunbar United.From there, it is on to Millfield , Foresters Parkand New Recreation Park .The cyclists will then head into Midlothian and tick off Kingrsquos Park , Newbattle Complex , New Victoria Park , Newbyres Park , New Dundas Park , Ferguson Parkand Penicuik Park .Then it is into the Capital for stops at Paties Road , Meggetland , Saughton Enclosure , Christie Gillies Park , Ainslie Park Stadium , St Marks Parkand finally Peffermill .Finally, the weary cyclists willto East Lothian and tick off Olivebankbefore reaching the finish line and familiar surroundings of The Pennypit .In total, the cycle, which is about  kilometres , is expected to take upwards of seven hours, with the players stopping for a photograph at each ground.The fundraiser is also the latest step on the road to recovery for midfielder Nathan.The -year-old missed the entire   season after a horror ankle injury in pre-season, which saw ligaments ripped off the bone.Now, he is keen to get back to fitness ahead of the new campaign kicking off.He said: ldquoI have still been going to watch matches and getting the changing room banter.ldquoWe are all in a group chat and a lot of the boys have been working on their fitness throughout lockdown.ldquoThey have been out running or cycling and a lot of the boys are keen to get back to it and we are all missing it, especially myself.ldquoI am hoping to be back for next season.ldquoIt has been a long hard battle to get back fit after surgery.ldquoIt has been three months since surgery and the doctor and physio said it would be three to six months before I am back playing.Nathan, who previously played for Musselburgh Windsor and Ormiston, has played at most of the grounds but will tick off visiting Haddington, Newtongrange Star, Arniston Rangers and Civil Service Strollers during the cycle.He was looking forward to the fundraiser and was pleased with the reaction from members of the public, with more than pound already donated.He said: ldquoMy mum is a carer, Irsquove got family and friends who work in the NHS, so it is a no brainer to be honest.ldquoMyself and Kai said we should half the money with the NHS. The work they are doing just now is remarkable.To support the club, go to www.justgiving crowdfunding prestonathletic

title: youth-project-takes-support-online
story: It runs daily challenges for young people through its lsquoZoom Youth Clubrsquo.Challenges, set at noon, are completed by youngsters who thenfor a feedback meeting later in the afternoon.The winner of each challenge is sent a prize.One parent said: ldquoThe online work you are doing is so much appreciated and my daughter loves it.ldquoShe particularly enjoys and looks forward to receiving the prizes and you can tell there is thought that goes into this ndash I cannot thank you enough.North Berwick Youth Project also hosts a P meeting every lunchtime Monday to Thursday, free yoga, a Netflix party and an activity evening, such as a quiz night, once a week.Another parent said: ldquoI think itrsquos been amazing that the children have had the chance to stay in touch, doing something thatrsquos been interactive and fun.ldquoSocialising digitally is so important right now to help their mental health.ldquoI want to teach my child that following the lockdown rules doesnrsquot have to be boring. title: social-enterprise-heavy-sound-finds-new-home-hub
story: The organisation, which champions community projects supporting the disadvantaged and young people, is moving into The Cockenzie Hub, formerly Cockenzie Business Centre, after taking on a three-year lease.The move will allow Heavy Sound, previously based in Tranent, to continue its work, with recent projects including refitting a bus with the help of prisoners at HMP Edinburgh, in Saughton, to create a mobile community centre.Heavy Sound uses rap, hip-hop, art and sports to work with young people from a iety of backgrounds.Jordan Butler, CEO of the organisation, said: ldquoFor the last five years we have been based in Tranent and, as a growing organisation, have found it dficult to find the right space in East Lothian to make a longer-term move.ldquoThe Cockenzie Hub is perfect for us we will be able to provide a full range of services as well as develop new programmes which will service Cockenzie and the wider community.The business hub was bought by Allied Surveyors Scotland on behalf of East Lothian-based Moscar LLP last October.Iain Mercer, of Allied Surveyors, welcomed the arrival of Heavy Sound to the hub.He said: ldquoThis underlines the demand for accommodation from local companies seeking affordable business space.

title: community-resilience-happening-dunbar-dunpender-north-berwick
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.DunbarDunbarAN APPEAL for unwanted laptops and tablets to be given to youngsters to help them study during the coronavirus has reached an impressive milestone.Community resilience volunteers in Dunbar called for the electronic devices to be donated.Each laptop and tablet is wiped clean, with ious upgrades carried out before they can be used by students.George Robertson, chairman of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership , was pleased to say the scheme had proven a success.He told the Courier: ldquoWe are up to  to  devices.ldquoThey have slowed quite a bit but we are still getting about two a day.ldquoThey all still require work and there is a bit of a backlog but they will get passed on to the schools when I can.Funding could also be secured to make sure the popular meal service, which has seen community resilience volunteers linking up with Home-Start East Lothian, continue.Hot meals prepared by a team of chefs are given to vulnerable members of the community throughout Dunbar and West Barns.A funding application is being drawn up in a bid to see the scheme extended.George, who is also a member of the townrsquos community council, said it had been an interesting experience being involved with the townrsquos resilience efforts.He said: ldquoIt has been very dferent.ldquoI think all the resilience groups around the county feel the same way.ldquoWe felt we were probably going to get involved when there was extreme weather or floods or some other disaster.ldquoThat would last a couple of weeks at most, certainly not something that lasts for months.ldquoIt has been dferent but we have been able to provide a service which is of great benefit to the few people who are vulnerable and without friends or family.ldquoIt has filled a very important need.Contact detailsTo find out more, e-mailDunbar.covid@gmailor call  .For more information, go to Dunbar and District Coronavirus Community Helpers atfacebook groups or Dunbar Community Council atfacebook DunbarCommunityCouncilEast Linton. Picture: Google MapsDunpenderVOLUNTEERS in East Linton are continuing to deliver hot meals three days a week to a number of households, and are also helping with shopping and collecting prescriptions for people who need support.Elsewhere, in the outlying parts of the Dunpender community ndash Whittingehame, Tyninghame and Whitekirk ndash residents continue to help their neighbours with shopping to avoid unnecessary journeys.The Lynton Centre has been delivering three-course meals to members and to those aged  and over or who are disabled and in need of this service.It can be contacted on  .A rota of its volunteers has been phoning members every day to keep their spirits up while they are unable to come to the Day Centre for social contact.Judith Priest, chairwoman of Dunpender Community Council, told the Courier: ldquoLocal shops here in East Linton have done a great job, making sure they have plenty of supplies and clear safety guidelines for shoppers.ldquoHome deliveries are available from The Mart and Linton Butchers."There is an organic vegetable stall at Phantassie on Saturdays and Bostock Bakery has been very popular, with cyclists stopping for a takeaway coffee and croissant.ldquoBarneyrsquos Coffee Shop is now open for a selection of gts and, of course, takeaway coffee and cakes, plus afternoon teas can be ordered for a treat delivered to your home.Contact detailsInformation relating to the coronavirus can be found at www.tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk or by going to www.eastlinton.ukPeople can also contact   or  .North Berwick.William Starkey and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.North BerwickQUILT makers in North Berwick are making a special lsquolockdown memoryrsquo quilt which they are hoping will be hung in the townrsquos community centre.Law Quilters, who celebrated their th anniversary last year, have been busy throughout the coronavirus crisis making quilts for ious uses in hospitals, hospices and womenrsquos refuges.They include lsquoLinusrsquo quilts for children, heart-shaped cushions for mastectomy patients and quilts for incubators, as well as face coverings.All of the quilt grouprsquos  members will be participating in the lockdown memory quilt.Moira Cochran, Law Quilters president, who is a retired nurse, said the group had come up with a number of images which will be included in the quilt.They include the unique signage warning people to stay two metres apart, baking ndash which has become incredibly popular during lockdown ndash a supermarket trolley full of toilet rolls, a computer screen with a Zoom meeting on it, rainbows, puffins and face coverings.Moira added: ldquoWe will also feature a lsquoThank You NHSrsquo image and a row of houses to represent the street links in North Berwick.Meanwhile,  volunteers led by Khlayre Cairney from North Berwick Resilience Group have stitched  face coverings so far from the cotton pillow cases and duvet covers donated to the community centre.ldquoTo date we have issued supplies to Astley House, North Berwick Day Centre, Tantallon Court, families being supported via the North Berwick Community Centre, and our own North Berwick volunteers, said Khlayre.Finally, more computer tablets have been distributed to care homes in the North Berwick area to enable residents to see and speak to relatives online.Three have been title: community-resilience-happening-cockenzie-port-seton-dirleton-longniddry-prestonpans
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fourof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.Cockenzie and Port Seton. Picture: Google MapsCockenzie and Port SetonTHE resilience team in Cockenzie and Port Seton has started to plan for how its work can continue once schoolsin August.The effort is being led by Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council.Bryan Hickman, group chairman, said: ldquoWe are working on what we will do when the schools go back. We will continue as best we can till then.ldquoWe are making plans.ldquoWhen the schools do go back, at the moment the plan is that they wonrsquot all go back at once so we might need to help families and kids while they are not at school.The resilience team is also discussing how its support efforts can continue during the easing of lockdown restrictions.The group received a third consignment of childrenrsquos craft packs from Walk With Scott Foundation, which are now being delivered throughout the community.The packs include items such as crayons, bee and butterfly colouring sheets and a butterfly feeding kit.Bryan extended his thanks to those at the Walk With Scott Foundation for their generous donation.Work on the sports hall extension at the Port Seton Centre has resumed after it was paused due to the coronavirus.Bryan told the Courier that the contractor was back on site and had resumed work on the pound million extension.Work initially started in October last year, with the hope it would be completed next month.Contact detailsThose in isolation, who are housebound or require assistance can still contact the team on  .Dirleton Castle.G Laird and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.DirletonVOLUNTEERS have vowed to continue offering support to people throughout Dirleton despite lockdown restrictions being eased.The Dirleton Area Resilience Teamis continuing its ongoing support for the local community.With the easing of pandemic restrictions and the lockdown, it has continued to be at the forefront of planning for, and critical analysis of, the situation.DARTrsquos primary services remain the same, with shopping and prescription requests being completed, dog walking being carried out and volunteers on hand to provide support when needed.David Tait, DART lead co-ordinator, said: ldquoAlthough the village and wider area seem to be gradually ing to normal, we are in no way complacent in our approach to the support we give.ldquoWe continue to monitor the situation on a day by day basis and we have contingency plans in place, ready for roll out in any eventuality ndash such as a possible second spike of the virus or to provide support to families who may be at risk when the furlough scheme is wound down and with the possibility of job losses.ldquoWersquore monitoring the position and we aim to keep our community up to date on whatrsquos happening as soon as we know about it.Meanwhile, the community essentials larder remains a vital asset within the village, with an increase in regular visits.The larder had been set to move to more permanent premises but this has been delayed.Jack Findlay, landlord of the Castle Inn in the village, has allowed DART to extend its time at the premises with the larder.David added: ldquoWithout Jackrsquos generosity we would have lost this vital asset, one on which our community continues to depend.ldquoWe are forever grateful to Jack and his family for the support they are giving to the DART team.ldquoThere arenrsquot enough words out there to thank them for their kindness.Contact detailsFor continued and up to date information on DARTrsquos activities, go to www.dirletonresilience.orgLongniddry. Picture: Google MapsLongniddryTHE resilience effort in Longniddry is still available for people who need to use it and the local dental practice has introduced new rules as part of its reopening during phase two of the easing of lockdown restrictions.Anyone who needs to contact the practice is asked to call first, as the door will be locked.People will be asked screening questions before appointments, which they are encouraged to attend alone.There will be hand sanitiser at reception and the toilet will remain closed.Appointments will be spaced out to allow for social distancing.People are being encouraged to pay using contactless methods and staff will be wearing additional PPE.Meanwhile, despite not receiving a lot of requests for help, the resilience effort is still available for those who need it.Longniddry residents can also benefit from the food pantry in Port Seton Centre.The pantry is open pm to pm, Monday to Friday.Delivery can be arranged by calling  .There is also a food pantry at the Pennypit Centre in Prestonpans, from am to pm.Contact detailsIf anyone needs support or assistance of any kind, they are asked to call Sheila Jamieson on  .Prestonpans. Picture: Google MapsPrestonpansPRESTONPANS community resilience effort is now looking at winding down some of its volunteer activities as members of its teamto work and demand for support reduces as people who have been shielding are allowed to got out under an easing of restrictions.Brian Weddell, chairperson of Prestonpans Community Council, said thoughts were turning to winding down resilience work after more than three months of ldquotremendous effort.But he stressed that the hardship fund set up by the community council to help those finding it dficult in lockdown remainsed and anyone who needed support could still call the resilience team for help.He said: ldquoOur thoughts are turning to winding down our resilience efforts. ldquoThere has been a tremendous amount of work put in by our volunteers in Prestonpans since the start of lockdown on March  and we cannot thank them enough for their support.ldquoAt the start of this, our volunteers delivered leaflets to every household in the Pans and during the past three months have delivered meals and shopping, collected food donated from supermarkets, collected prescriptions for people self-isolating and shielding and last, but not least, walked the dogs for people unable to get out.ldquoThe relaxation of the rules by the Scottish Government allows our volunteers to start to wind down but their magnicent efforts on behalf of their local community should not be forgotten.ldquoWithout their selfless efforts the past three months would have been a lot tougher for many people living in Prestonpans.Brian added: ldquoWhilst the work of our resilience volunteers is quietening down, le at the Pennypit Pantry carries on, with food parcels being delivered daily to the elderly, and many families now collecting food from the Pagoda in North Grange Avenue.ldquoLast week, the Pantry provided  meals to the elderly and families in Prestonpans, which included almost  deliveries each day.Anyone in Prestonpans who needs support with meals or essential groceries can call the Pennypit Pantry on   or email lornabellany@gmailAs well as the Pennypit Pantry, Jane Russellrsquos Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinners are still being provided, and last weekend they delivered  dinners.Sunday dinners can be ordered via East Lothian Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinners via its Facebook page or by calling  .Contact detailsAnyone who needs help can contact the team by calling their hotline telephone number on   or by emailing them at prestonpansresilience@gmail

title: emergency-services-called-two-car-collision
story: Firefighters from East Linton and Dunbar assisted the Scottish Ambulance Service at the scene shortly before pm.One motorist, who was on the scene, told the Courier a number of people on the scene were quick to try to help those in need.They said: ldquoI arrived, three cars and four helpers were on scene, and askedI could help.ldquoThere were very helpful bystanders one or two like myself with first aid training who were managing traffic and one helping the female driver.ldquoI saw the male driver was trapped, tried to assess danger, noticed smoke in car but quickly realised this was from airbags, others had ensured ignition off.ldquoThe male driver was lucid and talking, in pain, clearly a serious issue.ldquoWe all kept him talking and tried to have him remain calm when we called the emergency services.It is thought the accident involved a black car and a blue Porsche Boxster.A Police Scotland spokesperson said: ldquoAt around .pm on Friday, June , emergency services were called to the A between Lawhead and Tyninghame, following a two-car crash."There were not believed to be any serious injuries and the road was partially blocked for two hours before the cars were uplted.

story: It comes afteralmost days of lockdown, with the much-anticipatedreopening of the UKrsquos fast-food restaurants and pubs across England onJuly .Brits have been searching their favourites throughout lockdown on the off chance of them being open andFresh Student Livinghas delved into the nationrsquos cravings, looking at daily search data over the lockdown period to see just what the country has missed the most.One in tenBritsorder a takeaway at leastonce a weekand more thanhalf of us know exactly which restaurant we fancy before going online to order.What were the results Pizzas, burgers and donuts topped the list of foods we missed the most with more people searchingPizza Express, Burger King andKrispy Kreme than any other during lockdown.This is followed byPizza Hut,Subway,Nandorsquosand Dominos.FULL LIST: What weve beencraving: Pizza Express:Burger King:Krispy Kreme:Pizza Hut:Subway:Nandos:Dominos Pizza:Starbucks:Papa Johns Pizza:Greggs:Wetherspoons:McDonalds:Harvester:Toby Carvery:Five Guys:KFC:Bella Italia:Wagamama:Itsu:TGI FridaysWhat are the regional cravings NotablyMcDonaldstakes the regional crown coming in thetop two of nearly every region, includingLondon, BelfastandCardf. With theBig Mac, McMuffin, Happy Mealand McNuggets, being the dishes, we hankered for the most.InLiverpoolandManchester,Subway and Dominos topped the listof biggest cravings, and inGlasgow,Burger King and Subwaywere the choice picks.Interestingly itrsquosNewcastlewhere theyrsquoll be dining on Steak Bakes and Vegan Sausage rolls in the coming weeks asGreggs topped the search in only this location.

title: six-new-things-can-today-scotlands-lockdown-eased
story: The First Minister last week confirmed an acceleration of easing restrictions across the country following a continued suppression of the virus.But Nicola Sturgeonhas since urged the public not to ldquosquander that progress as we move into more freedom.Here, we detail out the six changes taking place today:Shopping and outdoor marketsOne of the most anticipated announcements from lockdown, non-essential shopsare now officially allowed to reopen.The one restriction still in place, however, is these must be street-access retail. Non-essential stores within shopping centres malls must remain closed until Phase .Commenting on the re-opening this morning, the First Minister tweeted: ldquoIf you plan on visiting shops today, please do so responsibly.ldquoMaintain physical distancing, follow hygiene advice, wear a face covering and respect staff who may be asking you to shop dferently.ldquoWersquove made so much progress against the virus ndash letrsquos not squander it. #StaySafe.Outdoor markets can also reopen, provided there can be controls on the number of people within the market and distancing is kept.On Friday, First Minister @NicolaSturgeon set out guidance on how to #StaySafe when some shops reopen today following changes to #coronavirus measures.Find out more ## https:t.co DwqbXAFMk pic VVuUhPzZWorkingWorking from home remains the default position.But the guidance says non-essential indoor, non-office based workplaces can reopen - including factories, warehouses, lab and research facilities.The construction sector can also implement further stages of a phased .This does NOT include indoor workspaces that are due to open in Phase  ndash like non-essential offices and call-centres.Moving homeFrom today, all home moves are permitted, provided they can be carried out safely.This includes students moving home and other home moves resulting in two households merging.It also applies to custom and self-builders looking to acquire a plot or a property to renovate or to demolish.The Scottish Government has issued guidance around this ndash as well as encouraging people to take part in virtual property viewings as much as possible with further guidance around health and safety here.Outdoor sports courts and playgroundsFrom today, outdoor sports courts can reopen to the public.This includes courts for tennis, basketball, volleyball , Multi-Use Games Areasand netball.Participants must maintain strict physical distancing at all times when using outdoor sports courts. This does not include pitches used for contact sports.Playgrounds can also reopen.These were closed at the start of lockdown amid fears the virus could spread through the physical contact in these areas.Marriages and civil partnershipsMarriages and civil partnerships can resume from today.These have to have a minimal number of attendees and, despite the Scottish weather, be outdoors only.All the participants, including the couple and the witnesses, must come from no more than three households and will be possible up to amaximum of eight.The celebrant or registrar will not count as one of the households.Zoos and garden attractionsMust to the anticipation of those in Edinburgh, zoos and garden attractions can open from today.However the Scottish Government guidance says these are initially for local access only ndash meaning people broadly within five miles can attend.Increased hygiene measures are encouraged, with pre-booking tickets online also advised.

story: First came queues of cars as McDonalds opened its drive-throughs, and now people rushed to the high streets as retailers were allowed to reopen their doors.In Glasgow, queues for the Argyle Street and Sauchiehall Street Primark snaked around the city centre from the early hours of the morning despite the pouring rain.Primark in Argyle Street, GlasgowLong lines were also seen at the Princes Street store in Edinburgh and Union Street branch in Aberdeen as enthusiastic shoppers ed to stores for the first time in months.Retailers were officially allowed to reopen this morning as part of further easing of lockdown restrictions during phase two of the Governments plans.But the enthusiasm of some shoppers left people ided.Shops finally opened again today in Scotland and honestly I am SO HAPPY that Irsquoll finally be able to buy smaller clothes that fit me ## yes Irsquoll be queuing for primark in the rain at some point this week ###However, while some were willing to withstand rain, others were not completely on board with the idea.I feel sorry for anyone getting soaked in the queue for Primark in town today. #### pic ntfpxJSJqIf you found yourself in a massive queue for Primark this morning then therersquos a % chance yoursquore an absolute zoomerHowever, others slammed the abundance of "snide" comments about the queues.Its easy to write a snide tweet about people queueing for Primark. title: east-lothian-council-shop-local-campaign
story: East Lothian Council has launched a campaign for residents to lsquoStay Safe, Support Local, Love East Lothianrsquo by using local shops and businesses.With many businesses hit hard by the Covid- pandemic, retailersacross the county re-opened this week and introduced social distancing measures to keep customers and staff safe.And the council is calling on people to back their local shops and services by using them while following safety advice.Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos Provost and spokesperson for economic development and tourism, said: ldquoEast Lothianrsquos shops and local businesses have had to face particularly challenging circumstances over the last few months, but, as our high streets start to open up again, they are keen to welcome existing and new customersldquoIrsquom delighted to support the launch of East Lothian Councilrsquos new campaign ndash Stay Safe, Support Local, Love East Lothian.ldquoItrsquos about sending out a message that East Lothian is getting back open for business ndash whatever products or services yoursquore looking for, yoursquore very likely to find them here in East Lothian.ldquoLocal businesses are essential for our economy. They bring growth and innovation, provide employment and support the local economies and communities. They also care about their community.ldquoBy continuing to stay safe and shop locally the people of East Lothian can help local businesses, so integral to the fabric and character of our community, to not only survive but thrive.The campaign comes as East Lothian councillor Craig Hoy, who is the Scottish Conservative candidate for the Holyrood  election, launched a locallsquoSupport Our High Streetsrsquo campaign.Mr Hoy has already called on the council to make it easier for local restaurants, cafes and bars to re-open by allowing them to use public space near their venues to provide al fresco services.He said: ldquoWith East Lothianrsquos shops re-opening, itrsquos vital that we Support Our High Streets, save jobs and help the local economy bounce back.ldquoWe can all do our bit by making sure we shop local and visit our fantastic range of cafes, restaurants and bars as they begin to re-open.

title: east-lothian-council-safe-space-funding
story: The local authority has been given pound.million of Scottish Government funding to allow it to transform its high streets and bring shoppers back.However, the plans have sparked concern among some residents, who questioned whether the council would use the money to introduce long-term changes proposed before lockdown which brought mixed reactions form the public.One person on social media accused them of using a ldquoback door to get what they want.While Haddington councillor Craig Hoy warned that improvements had to be made without creating unnecessary restrictionsHe said: ldquoIt is important that our high streets are capable of allowing pedestrians to be able to socially distance, giving people the confidence to get out and about.ldquoBut, at the same time, itrsquos important we donrsquot impose unnecessary restrictions or reduce parking provision in a way which is detrimental to trade.ldquoWe need to strike a careful balance here and ensure the interventions are proportionate.The local authority launched its bid for funds from the Spaces for People Fund last month with a public consultation online.It drew just under , responses, with  detailed comments about improvements for town centres and roads.Although the funding is for temporary measures, the online questionnaire asked those taking partthey would support changes ldquolong term.Many people who took part in the survey called for pavements to be widened and speed reductions on some streets, as well as improved cycle lanes and footpaths.The council initially said it was applying for pound, from the Spaces for People Fund but has revealed it received nearly four times the original amount.Councillor Norman Hampshire, depute council leader and environment spokesperson, said: ldquoThe pound.m funding will enable East Lothian Council to introduce a number of temporary measures to our streets as further easing of lockdown restrictions are applied.ldquoMany local shops are re-opening for business and these temporary changes are focused on protecting public health by providing necessary space for continued observance of physical distancing whilst supporting businesses and their customers.ldquoWhilst planning these new temporary changes, we have taken into account the erse needs of local communities to ensure as much as possible that those with mobility or sight concerns will be as supported as able-bodied iniduals.ldquoThese measures will create space for everyone, whether on foot, bike, wheelchair or using prams and buggies, and will support the initial stages of local economic recovery.The council said detailed plans of the changes to be introduced were still being discussed and no maps or additional information were currently available.However, it said a staged approach would be taken, with measures to be introduced including temporary widening of some footways, mph speed limits, some segregated space for cycling and opportunities for businesses to use pavement space for customer queuing.Some parking spaces within town centres may be temporarily removed.

title: rare-lunar-eclipse-visible-glasgow-weekend---need-know
story: One of only eight to occur this decade, all eyes will be on the skies early on Sunday morning.Here, we bring you everything you need to know ahead of the penumbral lunar eclipse.A penumbral lunar eclipse takes place when the moon moves through the faint, outer part of earths shadow.A lunar eclipse happens when the Earth comes between the sun and the moon, therefore blocking some or all of the sunrsquos light from reaching the moon.Therefore, the moon cannot shine ndash because its surface is not reflecting the sunrsquos rays.The eclipse will be visible over ScotlandAccording to TimeAndDate, a penumbral lunar eclipse occurs when the sun, earth and moon are imperfectly aligned.When this happens, the earth blocks some of the sunrsquos light from directly reaching the moonrsquos surface, and covers all or part of the moon with the other part of its shadow.People in Scotland are urged to find an unobstructed area with a free sight to the southwest for a best view of the eclipse.Unlike solar eclipses, which can only be seen along a narrow path from a small part of the earth, eclipses of the moon can be observed all across the night side of earth when the eclipse title: boxing-fan-floored-birthday-wish-world-champion-josh-taylor
story: Mckenzie Kearsley-Edmond celebrated turning  on June  and received a signed picture of Josh Taylor in action.However, it was a present he could not unwrap that really floored the youngster.Taylor, , took time out from his training regime to film a short video wishing Mckenzie, who hopes to follow in the boxerrsquos footsteps and join Lochend Amateur Boxing Club, a happy birthday.His dad Chris Kearsley, who lives in Dunbar, said: ldquoIrsquove never seen him so emotional in my le. He was just about in tears of happiness.The incredible gt came about through Chris, who is a self-employed joiner, getting in touch with Jenner Charlton.The Duns-based photographer has been a regular at Taylorrsquos fights and was able to not only arrange for a signed picture of the boxer in action against Ryan Martin but also line up the birthday message.Taylor, from Prestonpans but now living in Haddington, said: ldquoHi Mckenzie, hi wee man, happy birthday.ldquoHope you have a great day and Irsquoll see you at Lochend [Amateur Boxing Club] one day when it opens back up.ldquoWersquoll do a bit of training together.Mckenzie, who is going into P at Dunbar Primary School, has been clocking up the miles watching ldquohis hero.He has taken in fights in Glasgow and even met Taylor in unusual circumstances before the county fighter lted the IBF World Super Lightweight title against Ivan Baranchyk.His dad said: ldquoWe were staying at the Radisson RED in Glasgow and got into the lt on the seventh floor.ldquoThe lt stopped on the sixth floor and Shane and Barry McGuigan and Josh all got in and we got a picture with them.Mckenzie and his dad even travelled to London in October to see Taylor put his newly claimed world title up against Regis Prograis and his WBA World Super Lightweight championship.Chris said: ldquoIrsquove always been a boxing fan and kept up training for the last wee while.ldquoWe started following Josh and found out he was from Prestonpans.ldquoWe went to watch his fight with Viktor Postol in Glasgow, and Lynne Wilson [an ASN auxiliary at Dunbar Primary School] is Joshrsquos cousin.ldquoWe started going to Joshrsquos fights and Mckenzie became interested in boxing.ldquoHe joined the Bronx Boxing Gym in Tranent and was doing a bit of training there.ldquoWe went to all the World Boxing Super Series fights and went to the final in London against Regis Prograis.ldquoMckenzie was on cloud nine for a week afterwards it was a great atmosphere!

title: face-coverings-mandatory-scotlands-shops---rules-exempt
story: During her daily briefing, Nicola Sturgeon said the Scottish Government has been considering the issue of face coverings "for some time now".She confirmed it will become mandatory in Phase .Why the change Face coverings became mandatory in Scotland on all public transport on June .The First Minister said that "as we all start to interact more, it is vital that we take all reasonable steps to reduce risk."And we know that these coveringscan help reduce the risk of transmission indoors.""This is a really important wayfor all of us to help protect each other and to display that sense of solidarity that has served us well," she said.When does it become mandatory Ms Sturgeon said the enforcement will take place on Phase  - July .However sheurged Scots not to wait until next week, asking them to get into the habit now.How will it be enforced The First Minister said the rules will be enforced in a similar way to those on public transport.She said it would be "not fair or reasonable" to expect shop workers to enforce the rules - and instead it would be down to the police to do so.Fixed penalty notices - which start at pound - could be handed out by the police, but she says they will do so only at a last resort.Ms Sturgeon added: "All of us can help by doing this voluntarily because it can make a dference".Who is exempt Children under five will be exempt from this rule, Ms Sturgeon confirmed, along with those with certain medical conditions.Following in line with the public transport rules, then the following groups may also be exempt:But Ms Sturgeonsaid: ldquoFor everyone , face coverings will be mandatory."What  was announced MsSturgeon also announced that the two-metre social distancing rule can be reduced in the hospitality and retail sectors and on public transport at that time.Pubs, restaurants and shops will be allowed to adhere to a one-metre rule instead, with mitigation measures in place.But the general rule in law will be that businesses must take reasonable measures to ensure two-metre distancing is maintained, she said.The First Minister also said  patients have now died in Scotland after testing positive for coronavirus, up by one from  on Wednesday.A total of , people have tested positive for the virus, up by five from , the previous day.

title: tv-preview-natalie-dormer-playing-supernatural-demon-penny-dreadful-spin-off
story: The promise of "no makeup" was all it took to sell Rory Kinnear a role in Penny Dreadful: City Of Angels.Show creator John Logan had made the admission in an email subject line, aware that the British actor had previously spoken of his gruelling transition into Frankensteins Creature for the first iteration of the dark fantasy drama, Penny Dreadful.The lure of a simpler guise - in this case a German paediatrician - then, had successfully worked to secure hisfor its much-anticipated spin-off."I knew that something might be up, because Id often mentioned the fact that he made me have a three-and-a-half-hour makeup every day," realised Kinnear, ."So I was already interested - and then he sent me the script. He knew how to whet my appetite."Yet the characters arent the only element getting a makeover: billed as the originals "spiritual descendant", the brand-new -part series will transport viewers from Ripper-era London to the Golden Age of Hollywood in  Los Angeles.A time and place deeply infused with social and political tension, the sequel - which opens with a grisly murder - sees detectives Tiago Vegaand Lewis Michenerbattling the citys rich history. From the building of the first freeways and its traditions of Mexican-American folklore, to the dangerous espionage actions of the Third Reich and the rise of radio evangelism.In amongst the uprising, Kinnear plays Dr Peter Craft, a father of two who flits between caring paediatrician and his turn as head of the German-American Bund, an organisation he hopes will keep the United States isolated from the growing threat of war in Europe."Peter has a lot in common with a lot of characters in the show in that theyre all complex, conflicted, and struggling to do the right thing whilst coming up against temptation," says the star, whos also worked with screenwriter Logan on Bond films Skyfall and Spectre."He has a troubled home le, in that his we is an alcoholic and has seemingly cut herself off from looking after their children," he continues. "And his profession is all about looking after kids, so were expecting that [viewers] sympathise with him."But obviously in meeting Elsa, the path thats in front of him changes, and as a result the audience may have their sympathies change as well."Elsa is just one of a number of guises adopted by Natalie Dormers character, Magda.Dubbed a supernatural demon who can assume the form of anyone she chooses, the Game Of Thrones actress - whose character believes humankind is evil - has her work cut out, as she shts between blonde German housewe Elsa, government assistant Alex, and androgynous freedom fighter Rio.Her goal: to prove her point by nudging the city towards a race war.It was a major endeavour, says the -year-old, "in so far as its a physical and mental exercise because its four characterisations for the price of one"."We realised quite quickly that I had to play them as separate entities becauseyou dont play Elsa and Rio and Alex as fully fleshed out, three-dimensional characters, not only are you doing a disservice to your co-stars, the truth of the entire thing gets completely lost."And that actually, speaking in a pure sense as an actor, in terms of craft, its a joy because it means you have a lot of fun playing with the physicality, with voices, accents, and the costume and hair department..." she notes."I was very pleased to be a stage-trained, classically trained British actor because I really did go right back to my training, in order to do this sort of exercise. It was a nice challenge."Similarly, Kinnear states: "I like playing characters with lots of dferent shades [and] Peter comes upon a fairly invincible force in the shape of Elsa and Magda."But we dont know how much strength he has in him to withstand that temptation," he teases. "You see over the course of the  episodes that he does try, and hes also trying to stand up to the more radical, Nazi wing of the German-American Bund as well, to try and make the claim for peace."Peter is almost the inverse of the Creature, really he is trying desperately to push down his true identity and create someone completely anew. Whereas the Creature was in constant search of his origin and identity.""Magda has this theory that all mankind needs to become the monster he truly is, is to be told that he can, Dormer follows."For me, theres a bit of a premise that good people do bad things, whether its to do with threatening their family, their country or their vulnerability. Its that philosophical question of what it takes to bring out the uglier side in all of us."As for the shows key political themes - take othering, racism, and isions in society, for example - it seems theyre as relevant today as they ever were."What this shows is that all the tensions and dficulties of any large city, which has had a history of oppressing minority groups, have not gone away, and that they will continue to resurfacetheyre not fully addressed or addressed honestly," recognises Kinnear.Can he pinpoint a link between the first iteration and this "I think its that focus on how the supernatural plays out in real peoples lives and the strength of feeling that it can still provoke not only in the s, but today as well," he muses."The first Penny Dreadful was all about the monsters that lie within us and it was using largely pre-existing literary characters," reasons the father of two."This one focuses on that same thing, but also the sense of no matter how much you study and learn, there are things that exist beyond us, beyond our comprehension, which we try to give names to."That can lead to fears, whether irrational or not, but it can also give succour and strength as well."Is there room for another series "John is always several steps ahead," Kinnear finishes. "Not only is he so extraordinarily prolic in terms of all the output that he has, across so many dferent disciplines, he really enjoys it - and Penny Dreadful was his first time doing long-form TV!"There are lots of surprises thrown up in that, but you do have to plan your first three series because thats always the hope!"Watch all episodes of Penny Dreadful: City Of Angels on Sky Atlantic and streaming service NOW TV from Wednesday, July .

title: Opinion  Marianne Taylor  We   re all public health guinea pigs now    but that   s just the way it has to be
story: Irsquove also started planning a wee holiday up north and have booked a hairdressersrsquo appointment. Irsquove looked out my monthly cinema pass in anticipation of re-opening around July .I appreciate not everyone feels this way, but Irsquom ready to start living again. Irsquom also ready to accept some fundamental political realities.Letrsquos face it, wersquore all just guinea pigs now, part of a radical public health experiment the likes of which has never been attempted before. This experiment is reaching its most dficult phase yet, the bit where the Government has to somehow let people start doing normal things ndash like going back to work and spending money to keep the economy going ndash while simultaneously reminding us that we wersquore not out of the woods yet. They have to encourage people to go out, while keeping them scared.Many ndash including me ndash have criticised politicians for their missteps and mixed messages over the last few months. But I also recognise a number of basic truths that itrsquos better to get onersquos head around sooner rather than later, regardless of party politics.The first is that until coronavirus has been completely eradicated around the world, risk is going to play a part in our lives for the foreseeable future. The second is closely related: the state cannot tell us exactly how to manage this risk in every single circumstance. We may get health advice and government guidance, but ultimately we have to navigate this new, more precarious world on our own.How we do this, and, crucially, how we feel about doing it, depends on many dferent things, of course, not least our age and underlying health, our financial situation and, to a signicant extent, our personality.I know there are some who believe that through lting lockdown restrictions politicians in Westminster and Holyrood are very deliberately handing over responsibility ndash and thus blame ndash to the public for what comes next. And there may be some truth to this. But come on, letrsquos get real.Accusations of ldquomaking it up as they go along are thrown around asthis was an insult rather than simply a fact describing the predicament governments everywhere find themselves in. How could it be otherwise given the extraordinary events of the last six months  And whatrsquos the alternative to us being public health guinea pigs  Staying at home forever Community levels of the virus in Scotland are now low and falling. Our hospitals lie empty. We have a test and trace system in place to ndash hopefully ndash crack down on infections. Meanwhile, wellbeing continues to suffer under the restrictions and hundreds of thousands of jobs hang in the balance. All of these things mean we can and should lt the lockdown. And lting restrictions means the vast majority of folkmust decide for themselves what level of risk they are comfortable contending with, taking into consideration how it might affect their family and community as well as their own personal circumstances.We can help ourselves along the way. Firstly by staying up to date ndash through trusted, legitimate scientic and public information sources ndash about how the virus is transmitted and the best ways to stay safe.We can also resist the temptation to judge others for their decisions. Frankly, Irsquom sick of the army of armchair virologists spouting their culture war vitriol on social media. On one side you have those who seem to relish the lockdown, the class swots who shout too loudly about how they follow every part of the guidanceand seem to revel in the idea of a second wave. On the other side, you have the virus deniers. Both groups peddle fear and misinformation, whether that is their intention or not.At the end of the day none of us, not even the scientists, know whether and when there will be another wave of the virus. Uncertainty permeates through every part of our lives now, and we must find ways to live with and even embrace thiswe are to make it through the tough months ahead. Letrsquos at least try to respect each otherrsquos dferent ways of coping, shall we All columnists are free to express their opinions. They donrsquot necessarily represent the view of The Herald.

title: Opinion  Rosemary Goring  Why the Border must regain its old role as the country   s first line of defence
story: Yet she is clearly unsettled at the idea of some kind of checkpoint on the A, A, or whichever route she might take. Speculation over testing or quarantining travellers between England and Scotland has been raised as part of a discussion of how to prevent infection from a neighbour with a higher incidence of Covid  than here. As a result, almost overnight the Border has begun to assume a signicance it has not held for centuries.:Thousands back petition to close Scottish border to all but essential trafficThis pandemic might one day be viewed as a textbook illustration of the geopolitical fault lines across the UK. What was once a united front has splintered into four distinct nations, each with a dferent solution to the same problem. Nothing more starkly demonstrates the gulf between the laissez-faire ethos of the Westminsterrsquos panjandrums and the commonsensical attitude at Holyrood than the ways in which they have eased restrictions.The increasingly relaxed English regime appears to be fuelled by wishful thinking rather than science the Scottish situation, meanwhile, is characterised by caution. Long before talk of checkpoints, this was already causing tension. When Englandrsquos routemap out of lockdown was weeks ahead of Scotland, John Lamont, Conservative MP for Berwickshire, Roxburgh and Selkirk, said those of his constituents close to Borisrsquos bailiwick were confused. Why did one rule apply to their very near neighbours, and another to them The answer seemed obvious ndash it was far too soon to relax ndash but the question vividly demonstrated the nature of this area. Many who live where Hadrianrsquos men boldly marched have a foot in both countries. They might work in one, and live in the other, hail from this side and have relocated to that. They could have family and friends in either camp, who remained out of reach for so long as the Scottish government prohibited meeting.Those Border villagers who defied lockdown to visit a garden centre in Berwick were making a political rather than a horticultural statement. In this, they echoed attitudes since the days of the great reiving clans, who roamed freely on both banks of the Tweed. The Scottish and English kings were so appalled at the regionrsquos lawlessness that, despite being sworn enemies, they worked in tandem to subdue it.Given the way Borderers were treated by their lieges, itrsquos no surprise they thumbed their noses. These days, towns and villages are awash with folk from both sides, thereby creating a unique and strongly bonded region. Little wonder Unionism still pertains hereabouts.:Tourists from England could face -day quarantine in ScotlandCovid- cases flareThat there have been no deaths from Covid  in Scotland for the past few days suggests we are heading in the right direction. But there is a long way still to go. The First Ministerrsquos aim is to eradicate the virus, not merely contain it. Seeing the daily tally of new cases and deaths in England, she seeks confirmation that the Prime Minister has the same objective. But, as she said earlier this week, without such assurances she fears Englandrsquos strategy is ldquoletting it circulate at higher levels as long as it doesnrsquot threaten to overwhelm the NHS.If that is indeed the case, then monitoring passage between the countries is in some respects no dferent from policies implemented by a place like New Zealand. It initially imposed an outright ban on entry, followed later by quarantine on new arrivals.
